First check whether the lumped-capacitance approach is valid: compute the Biot number Bi = h·Lc/k (use a representative length Lc = V/A). If Bi ≪ 0.1, internal temperature gradients are small and the body acts like a single thermal mass. Identify h, surface area A, volume V, density ρ and specific heat cp; the characteristic time scale τ is set by the thermal capacitance divided by the convective conductance (thermal mass ≈ ρVp*c divided by hA). As a rule of thumb, a time on the order of τ reduces the object’s excess temperature to roughly 37% of its initial value above ambient—use these checks to decide if a simple lumped exponential model is appropriate before solving further.

turns.content: For a lumped-capacitance solid undergoing transient conduction, what fraction of the initial temperature difference between the solid and the surrounding fluid remains after one thermal time constant (t=τ)?

turns.content: Conduction is heat transfer by microscopic energy exchange driven by temperature gradients (Fourier’s law: q = -k∇T). For a transient problem first check the Biot number Bi = h·Lc/k — if Bi ≪ 0.1 the lumped-capacitance model is valid and the solid’s temperature is nearly uniform; its temperature change is then governed by an ODE with an exponential decay characterized by a thermal time constant τ given by the ratio of stored thermal capacitance to the external heat-transfer rate (τ = ρVc_p/(hA_s)).
